loans.name: Mrs. Sun Thyda Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of twenty people who live in Mreah Prov village in Takeo province. Mrs. Sun T. is the village bank president who has been selected by the others in the group.   The members will use their portion of this loan in varied ways to improve the living conditions for their families.

Mrs. Sun T. is a rice trader who is able to earn some profit to support her family.   Her husband, Mr. Net Chheng, works as a pig slaughterer to earn income to support his family.  

Recently, Mrs. Sun T. wants to buy a breeding cow, but her savings is not enough.  To achieve this purpose, she is applying for a loan to add to her savings to buy a cow for breeding to start a new business. She is a mother of a child who is 6 months old.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Fokaben Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Fokaben, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 48 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Siemana, préfecture de Barouéli ; Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de condiments, d’argile blanche et des céréales.                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe Fokaben sont à leur sixième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter du sel de cuisine, du riz et de l’argile blanche.                                                                         
SITAN T. compte acheter des sacs de sel de cuisine avec les revendeurs de Barouéli. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement sur place à la maison et le plus souvent au marché de Konobougou, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en: The women in the Fokaben group are all married and on average are 48 years old with 3 children. They all live in traditional extended families in the village of Siemana, Barouéli prefecture, Ségou Region (fourth administrative region of Mali). They know one another through ties of community, kinship and friendship. They sell condiments, white clay and grains.  The women in the Fokaben group are on their sixth solidarity loan, which will be used to buy cooking salt, rice, and white clay. Sitan T. plans to buy bags of cooking salt from Barouéli retailers. She sells her products daily at home and most often at the  Konobougou market, in cash and on credit, to a clientele of men and women. She expects to earn a monthly profit of 20,000F CFA which will be used to pay the loan installments and to make contributions to social ceremonies.  The remainder will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: To buy cooking salt

loans.name: Enhchimeg

texts.en:
Enhchimeg, 29, is married and lives with her husband in the Hentii province of Mongolia. They live in a house that they own and have a decent standard of living. Her husband owns and operates a taxi, transporting people between cities and traveling seven or eight times a month. 

Enhchimeg began selling clothes in 2008. She operates a rented stall at a local trading center. Her monthly income is between 1,500,000 and 1,800,000 MNT. The trading center where she operates her stall is located on a busy street which is an advantage for her business. Enhchimeg is requesting a loan of 2,500,000 MNT to purchase more clothing for her business. She is a modest and hardworking regular customer of our bank who says, "I would like to carry on this business and expand it since I support my family with the income from this business. I want to increase the amount and variety of goods that I sell."

loans.use: To purchase more clothing for sale

loans.name: Batjargal

texts.en:
Batjargal is a 49-year-old man who lives with his wife and daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He supports his family by running a carpentry business with help from his son. His daughter is a student while his wife works as a teacher at the local public school. His family lives in a small house in the outer ger (nomadic tent) districts of the city. 

When Batjargal first began his carpentry business in 1995, he used to rent a workplace to make furniture with 300,000 MNT of working capital. His business has grown since and today he has 6,000,000 MNT of working capital. He makes furniture at his own workplace, which is next to his small house, and he sells them at Narantuul, the largest outdoor market in Mongolia. For the last 16 years, Batjargal has been supporting his family as well as improving their living conditions with his business profits. For the last two years, he built a workplace plus a small house for his son and managed to buy a car for himself. With this loan of 2,000,000 MNT he will purchase more wooden panels to produce more furnishings.

loans.use: To purchase more wooden panels to produce more furnishings

loans.name: Uuganbayar

texts.en:
Uuganbayar, 31, is married and lives with his wife in a house that they own in the Selenge province of Mongolia. His wife currently works for an NGO. Uuganbayar began operating a PC game center in 2007. Now he has a photography studio that he began operating in 2009. He learned the Photo Shop program when he used to operate his PC game center. 

Uuganbayar wants to continue his business and expand it further. He is requesting a loan of 800,000 MNT to upgrade some of his tools and to purchase a printer and scanner. Uuganbayar is a hardworking and proactive person who is trying hard to have a bigger photo studio. His wish is to have his own place where he can operate his photography studio and computer business.

loans.use: To purchase a printer and scanner

loans.name: Chhan

texts.en:
Chhan C. is a widower from Phnom Penh City, Cambodia.  He has been retired from his work for a few years and is living with his five single children.  Two of his children are married and live independently.  His five single children work in different jobs – four are sewing worker and receive fixed salaries, and they always contribute their earnings to Chhan C. to use for the whole family’s needs.  

Chhan C.’s children have been paying money for taxis to get to work because they don't own a vehicle. To solve this problem, he is applying for a loan to purchase a motorcycle, which will allow his children to commute to their work locations.

loans.use: To purchase motorcycle for commuting

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a new rickshaw

loans.name: Angelique

texts.en: Angelique is 35 years old and has three children who are between the ages of 1 and 11 years old. She owns a shop from which she sells several items such as rice and sugar, and her husband works with her. Angelique is requesting a loan in order to buy more items to sell in her store.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, rice etc. for her store

loans.name: Motema Mpiko Plus Group

texts.en:
Mayele is the leader of the group named “Motema Mpiko Plus” made up of 15 members firmly united to receive loans from Kiva's partner, HOPE RDC, in order to develop their businesses. Mayele is 36 years old, married and has two children between the ages of 2 months and 5 years old. One of them attends school. Mayele sells shoes in his town, located southwest of Kinshasa. He has been in business since 2003. He has acquired solid experience in this area and works hard with good management skills to achieve his dream of one day opening a shoe shop. 

He would also like to achieve financial independence through his business that earns about $100 per week. He works to the best of his abilities and uses his contacts so that he might achieve his goals. Mayele is a trustworthy client of HOPE RDC, having five times obtained and timely repaid loans. He will increase his stock of products with his next loan by buying more shoes and reselling them at a profit.

loans.use: To increase his stock of shoes and resell them at a profit

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Dieu Vivant Plus Group

texts.en:
Jules is the leader of the Community Bank named “Dieu Vivant Plus” which is composed of 17 members united in solidarity for receiving Kiva loans with the goal of developing their businesses. Jules has five children between ages 8 and 17 years old. All of them attend school. Jules is 50 years old, married, has been part of the micro-enterprise world since 2004. 

He operates a general store to the west of Kinshasa. He has acquired solid experience in this area and works hard with good management skills in order to realize his dream of one day opening a food store. He would also like to achieve financial independence through his business that earns him $100 per week. He works to the best of his abilities and uses his contacts so that he might achieve his goals. Jules is a trustworthy client of Kiva's partner, HOPE RDC, having five times obtained and timely repaid loans. He will increase his stock of merchandise with his next loan by buying 25 crates of drinks and reselling them at profit.

loans.use: To increase his store’s stock of drinks and resell them at profit

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Violette

texts.en: Violette is 30 years old and her husband is a soldier. Violette owns a shop from which she sells several item such as rice, sugar etc. and she has been in this business for 4 years. She is now requesting a loan in order to buy more items for her shop and hopes to reinvest in her business with the profits she hopes to make.

loans.use: To buy items such as rice and sugar to sell

loans.name: Surbeh Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, Northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you members of the “Surbeh” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Kenema city, in Eastern Sierra Leone. They are requesting a loan of 500,000 SLL each to enable them to further improve on the size and quality of their respective businesses.

Pictured on the left is Gbessay B. who is the leader of this group. Gbessay was born in Kailahum. She is married to an engineer, and the couple has two children.

Gbessay sells fruits and has been doing this business for 10 years now. With her share of the loan, she will expand her business by buying a larger quantity of fruits to add to her current ones.

loans.use: To purchase fruit

loans.name: Violette

texts.en: Violette is 31 years old and she has a 5 month old child. She is a tailor and her husband is a moto-taxi driver. Violette is requesting a loan in order to to buy tailoring equipment. She plans to use the profits from the loan to reinvest in her tailoring business.

loans.use: to buy tailoring equipment

loans.name: Kawthar

texts.en:
Kawthar, who is married to Adham, is a mother of two daughters (Sawsan and Tamam) and one son (Haitham). Kawthar’s husband is a taxi driver in Rafah city in Gaza Strip. Kawthar’s husband has been a taxi driver for five years. His car is the only source of income and it needs maintenance. Therefore, Kawthar took a loan from FATEN so that her husband can cover the expenses.

Kawthar’s husband appears in the picture here, as Kawthar is a conservative woman.

loans.use: To cover car maintenance expenses

loans.name: Little Is Much Group

texts.en:
Bendu G., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of four borrowers called Little Is Much. She is 39 years old, married, and has three children between the ages of 9 and 19 years old. Bendu G. was only able to attend school through 10th grade due to financial constraints. She describes herself as an easy-going and kind woman whose dream is to improve her business.

Bendu G. has been selling charcoal in Brewerville Community outside of Monrovia, Liberia for 2 years. She plans to use her 15,000 LRD portion of this 60,000 LRD business loan to buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.use: to buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Hae-Nna Meleka Group

texts.en:
Roxton F., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of four borrowers called Hae-nna Meleka.  He is 42 years old, married and has three children between the ages of 3 and 22 years old. Roxton F. was only able to attend school through 11th grade due to financial constraints. 

Roxton F. has been selling building materials in New Georgia Community, Monrovia, Liberia for 7 years. He plans to use his 15,000 LRD portion of this 60,000 LRD business loan to buy more building materials to resell. Roxton F. describes himself as a God-fearing man whose dreams are to improve his business and to continue educating his children.

loans.use: to buy more building materials to resell

loans.name: Tahreer

texts.en:
Tahreer is a young woman from Jenin city. Tahreer is married and has no children, Tahreer decided to start treatment in order to have a baby.

As Tahreer, who is photographed in the picture above in FATEN's office, and her husband are working in a police force with a decent salary that doesn't cover the treatment's expenses, she decided to take a loan from FATEN to pay for the fertility drugs and repay on a monthly basis.

loans.use: To cover fertility drugs and treatment

loans.name: Janet P.'s Group

texts.en:
Meet the teachers of the R.C. Hanga Road I Primary School, situated in Kenema city. R.C. Primary School was built in September 1970 by the Roman Catholic mission. The school is staffed with 24 teachers and has an enrollment of 780 pupils.  This is the first loan that teachers of R.C. Primary School are requesting from SMT/Kiva lenders.  With the help of this loan, these teachers’ standard of living will improve. 

Janet P. S., aged 44, is the leader of this group of teachers. She was born in Bunumbu village, and she is married, with 2 children – one is in college and the other is in secondary school. Janet has been a teacher for 24 years. She will use her share of this loan to buy house-building materials such as bags of cement and boards.

loans.use: To buy house-building materials such as cement and boards

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a young man from Jabalia refugee camp. Ali runs a small grocery store. He is engaged and wants to get married next summer.
Ali took a loan from FATEN to purchase a large variety of goods and expand his business in order to have a better income and be able to cover the wedding expenses and buy the items he needs for his house.

Ali appears in the picture above.

loans.use: To purchase a larger amount of goods to sell

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

She operates a general store, selling mattresses, bedsheets and printing papers to her neighbors. Agnes faces a major challenge of seasonality. During rainy season, the price of the products increases and demand decreases. In the future, she hopes to establish a wholesale shop to sell mattresses.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase mattresses, bedsheets, reams of printing paper and body lotions to sell. She decided to join Yehu to access funds to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase mattresses, bedsheets, reams of printing paper and body lotions to resell.

loans.name: Louis

texts.en:
Louis is a single woman with one child who attends school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

She has operated a beauty salon business for the past five years.  Her potential customers are neighbors and passersby. Louis faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. During rainy season it becomes a challenge to operate her business. She hopes to expand and build rental houses.

With the loan of Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase two blow dryers, 30 razor blades and hair oil. Louis joined Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase blow dryers and razor blades

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
Mwanajuma is a married woman with nine children:  three girls and six boys. One still attends school, and the others have all graduated. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

She sells dumplings at the market to her neighbors.  She also sells palm leaves, providing another source of income. Mwanajuma faces a major challenge of expensive transportation, especially during rainy season. She hopes to educate her children and diversify her business. 

With the loan of Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase three bundles of wheat flour, cooking oil and palm leaves. She joined Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase three bundles of wheat flour, cooking oil and palm leaves.

loans.name: Christiana P.'s Group

texts.en:
These are teachers of the Holy Rosary Primary School, based in Kenema city. This school was founded in September 1956 by the Catholic Mission to improve the education of female children. Teachers of the Holy Rosary Primary School have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, to seek a loan. 

This is the first loan that teachers of the Holy Rosary Primary School have sought from SMT/Kiva lenders. They have requested a loan of SLL 4,500,000 for the entire group. With the help of this loan, these teachers will be in a better position to buy or invest in items that their salaries alone cannot provide.

Christiana P. K. is the leader of the group. She is 54 years old. She was born in Baiima village. Christiana is a widow and has four children. She has been in the teaching profession for many years. She has requested this loan in order to buy house-building materials like iron, corrugated zinc. and bags of cement.

loans.use: To buy house-building materials such as iron, corrugated zinc and cement

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Wilson is 48 years old and married to Margaret Kibusia, who is a housewife. They have three school-going children, namely Moses Kipkurui, Leah Jepchirchir and Kipkemoi Kibusia. He has been in the business of buying and selling cattle for 20 years and right now his monthly income is 6,000 KES.

He is borrowing a loan of 20,000 KES which he wants to pay school fees for his son. He plans to use the anticipated profit from his business to educate his children. This is his fourth loan and he successfully paid his previous loans well and in good time.

His dreams and hopes are to be a successful business man who can fully support his family and especially give the best education to his children.

loans.use: To pay his son's school fees

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy new beauty products & dresses, and to improve her salon.

loans.name: Yakubjon

texts.en:
I. Yakubjon is 27 years old and married. He is a farmer who owns a plot of land in his village where he grows different kinds of crops such as wheat, potatoes, onions and other vegetables. Yakubjon has been in this business since 2004 and these crops are the main source of income for his family. To alleviate the hard physical labor and to expand the business, Yakubjon would like to apply for a loan to purchase seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants.    
 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants

loans.name: Bokhdir

texts.en:
K. Bokhdir is a simple farmer with simple dreams – to uplift his family’s economic life and to be able to eventually send his dearest children to university. Farming has been his major source of income. Bokhdir produces wheat, potatoes and onions. He is requesting a loan of 1,200 USD to support his farming business and to avoid asking for credit from merchants charging higher rates of interest. He is grateful that he is able to borrow from lenders that offer low interest and help create better opportunities in people's lives, thereby helping his family to be free from poverty. Bokhdir said that through prayers and hard work, his dreams can be achieved someday. Providing his children with education is one of Bokhdir's important priorities.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela is a married woman with five children, three of whom attend school while two have already graduated from school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

Pamela has operated a business selling clothes for the past ten years, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. Pamela faces a major challenge of seasonality. During the rainy season, the buying price of clothes goes up and the demand goes down. She hopes to establish a rental housing business in the future.

Pamela plans to use this KES 20,000 loan to purchase bundles of t-shirts, ladies fashions and mattress covers for sale. She decided to join Yehu because of the low interest rates of loan products.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of t-shirts, ladies fashions and mattress covers

loans.name: Islom

texts.en:
N. Islom, 39, is married and has 6 children. He lives in Kumsangir, Tajikistan and works in the agricultural industry. Fifteen years ago he decided to begin to cultivate land that he owned in order to generate more income to support his family. Islom grows wheat, corn and vegetables, which he must care for properly in order to produce a full, healthy harvest. He will use the loan money to buy supplies to improve production yield. Over the years, Islom has discovered that he enjoys doing this job and that is why he will continue to use loans to improve his farm and become a better farmer.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Reynolds Lamin's Group

texts.en:
This group is made up of teachers at the KMDEC School - Gandor in Kenema city. This school was established in September 2001 by the District Educational Committee in order to help meet the Millennium Development Goal, i.e. Education For All.
 
School staff from this institution, like many other schools' staff within SMT’s operational areas, comes to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise be unable to accomplish with their meager salaries. With the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, housebuilding materials, or invest in business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayments and pays SMT on their behalf.

Reynolds Lamin V., 62 years old, is the leader of this group of teachers. Reynolds was born in Sami Fulluma. He is married to a merchant and the couple has 7 children – 4 adults, 2 attending secondary school and 1 in college. Reynolds is going to use his share of this loan to buy house building materials such as iron, corrugated zincs, cements, and iron rods.

loans.use: to buy house building materials

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth K. is 40 years old and married to Kipngetich Barmasai, who is a primary school teacher and supports his family with his salary.  They are blessed with two children: Kiplabat Ngetich and Jepkemoi  Ngetich.  Both children are in class eight. She does dairy farming and has been in this business for ten years with a monthly income of 8,000 KES. 

She is borrowing a loan of 39,000 KES with which she plans to purchase dairy feed for the cows in order to achieve quality milk production. She plans to use the anticipated profit from the business to educate her children to a higher level.

This is her third loan and she successfully repaid her previous loan. Her dreams and hopes are to become a successful farmer and to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy dairy feed for cows

loans.name: Akbarali

texts.en:
R. Akbarali is married and the father of 3 children. For three years he has been engaged in the farming business. His love for his children is the motor that keeps him working hard for their future. Akbarali works fast with the help of his wife to create quality products. But the high prices of fertilizer have caused his production to slow down, and he wishes to do better, produce more crops and increase the number of hectares. To do it, Akbarali needs capital, which he is requesting through this loan and hopes that you can help him. This way he can look forward to a more profitable production to increase his income and pay for his children’s education. 
  
More about Tajikistan:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. IMON's History:

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase more seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda G. is from the village of Namnama, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 45 years old. Imelda is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Imelda owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector selling religious items. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling general religious articles to tourists and local community members. Imelda has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Imelda joined Kiva's partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Imelda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Imelda is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional items for sale. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Imelda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional religious items to sell

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is a married man with five children, all of whom attend school. He owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is school fees.

He has operated a motorcycle business for the past six years, passengers are his potential customers. In addition he also has a photography business which contributes as another source of income. He hopes to purchase a car to operate a cab business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 loan he is requesting, he wants to purchase another motorcycle. He decided to join Kiva's partner, Yehu, because of its loan product efficiency.

loans.use: To purchase another motorcycle.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice O. is 24 years old and the single mother of one child. She lives in Usenge, which is on the outskirts of Kisumu County.

Beatrice has a motorcycle business that she has been running for three years. She is applying for her third loan from KADET Ltd. to enable her to buy another motorcycle to add to her business. She wants to seize the opportunity as most people use motorcycles for transportation and that business is doing well.

Her desire for the future is to be able to own a car which can be used as a taxi.

loans.use: To buy another motorbike

loans.name: Mahmadmurod

texts.en:
S. Mahmadmurod is 41 years old. He is married and the father of two children. Mahmadmurod is an optimistic, hardworking father. He works his land with love and dedication every day, so that it produces excellent vegetables. Mahmadmurod has been in agrobusiness for more than 4 years. In fact, he draws strength and vitality to make his products the best in the city. His loving wife is also engaged in this business. Though growing vegetables is a very difficult and time consuming job, he hopes to gather a rich harvest. He is planning to fix the house and save enough money to improve the well-being of his family. With this purpose he is requesting a loan of $2200 USD. Mahmadmurod appeals to your generous hearts for a swift contribution.   

More about Tajikistan:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase more seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: United Business Associate Group

texts.en:
Austine S., who is holding the sign in the photo, is the leader of this group of three borrowers called United Business Associate. He is 38 years old, married, and has four children who are between the ages of 5 and 15 years old. He is a high school graduate.

For 2 years, he has been involved with soap making and selling in New Georgia outside of Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his portion of this 45,000 LRD loan to buy more gallons of red oil and caustic product used in the soap production process. He describes himself as a devoted man whose goals are to improve his business and build a house.

loans.use: To buy more gallons of red oil and caustic product to produce more soap for sale

loans.name: Bakhtiyor

texts.en:
Z. Bakhtiyor is 31 years old, married, and lives with his wife and two children. He has been a farmer for the past 8 years. He began with the goal of supporting his household and, above all, to satisfy the needs of his children. For Bakhtiyor, agriculture is an activity that he likes to do. Within farming, vegetable production is what he likes most as it is easier to cultivate these plants and the product is profitable in season, which is annually. 

Now Bakhtiyor wishes to borrow money to invest in seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants. He is sincerely grateful for your support.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of seeds, mineral fertilizer, fuels and lubricants.

loans.name: Papin

texts.en: Papin M. is 52 years old. He lives in Zovaber village, an area of Sevan, with his wife and his two sons. Papin’s wife works at a village school as a foreign language teacher. His elder son is jobless and his youngest son is a student. Papin worked as an engineer for a long time and since 2000, he has been engaged in farming. Papin raises cows, sheep, pigs and chickens and he grows potatoes. His wife helps him a lot and so they keep their family and pay for their youngest son’s education. Papin is asking for a 1,000,000 AMD loan to buy potato seedlings for his farm.

loans.use: To buy potato seedlings for his farm

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She has operated a cafe business for the past six months, selling to her neighboring community members. Christine faces a major challenge of price fluctuation of commodities in the market. She hopes to expand her business and establish a restaurant business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000, she wants to purchase bundles of maize flour, beans and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu because of the efficiency of the loan products.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of maize flour, beans and cooking oil.

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en:
Cynthia is 29 years old and a hard working single lady. Cynthia practises small scale farming whereby she plants vegetables to sell.  At the same time she also sells used clothes known locally as mitumba  Her monthly income from the business is 33,000 KES.

She is borrowing a loan of 30,000 KES with which she plans to add more stock of second hand clothes, and also buy some fertilizer for the farm. She plans to use the anticipated profit to purchase a lorry for transporting the vegetables from the farm to the market place where she can easily reach her customers.

This is her second loan and she successfully paid her previous loan well and in good time. Her dreams and hopes for the future are to purchase a tractor for ploughing.

loans.use: To buy farm fertilizer and add more stock of second hand clothes

loans.name: Temps De Grace Plus Group

texts.en:
Gyka is the leader of the group named “Temps de Grace Plus”.  This group is made up of 9 members firmly united to receive loans from the MFI (micro-finance institution) HOPE RDC in order to develop their businesses.

Gyka’s main business is selling slippers in his area, located south east of Kinshasa. Since 2004, he has acquired solid experience in this area and works hard with good management skills in order to achieve his dream of one day opening a shoe shop. He would also like to achieve financial independence through his business, which currently earns him $10 per day. He works to the best of his abilities and uses his contacts so that he might achieve his goals. 

Gyka is a trustworthy client of the MFI HOPE RDC's, having obtained and correctly repaid fifteen loans.  With this new loan, he will increase his stock of products by buying slippers and reselling them at a profit. 

68-year-old Gyka is married and has six children aged between 18 and 39 years old. Two of them still attend school.

loans.use: To purchase shoes to resell

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: A solar powered kit

loans.name: Sorie S.'s Group

texts.en:
Salone Micronfinace Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni northern Sierra Leone, is very please to present to you the teachers of the King Fahad Mission Primary School.  These members of this school have come to SMT for the first time to seek a loan of SLL 2,400,000.00 in order to buy furniture, house building materials, and pay school fees for their children.

Sorie S. K. is the leader of this group of teachers. This 44-year-old was born in a village call Mange Loko. He is married to a businesswoman and the couple has 7 children.  Sorie is a teacher and has been in the profession for 6 years. He has requested a loan of SLL 700,000 from Kiva lenders in order to buy house building materials and to pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: Buy house building materials and pay school fees for his children

loans.name: Josefridah

texts.en:
Josefridah is a 46-year-old single lady.  To earn a living, she provides video shooting and editing services.  She also rents out houses to supplement her income.  She has been running her business for thirteen years.  

Josefridah started the business with only one computer.  Now, she owns nine computers as well as other machines which she bought through loans fromFaulu Kenya.  She dreams of owning a studio in five years. With this loan for 66,000 Kenyan shillings, she will buy another computer.

loans.use: To buy a computer for video editing business

loans.name: Jacques

texts.fr: Jacques Nyarugabo est consultât du ministère de santé au Rwanda, il est né en RDC (congo). Il a 40 ans et a 8 enfants entre 20 et 2 ans, enfants vont à l’école. Il un diplôme de niveau A0 en sociologie. Il est client d’ACB depuis 2008. Il besoin d’un prêt pour faire soigner son fils qui a un problème de la colonne vertébrale, amis lui aussi a connu un accident de taxi moto. Ses ambitions sont de travailler à la hâte pour rembourser le crédit, enfin il veut chercher un nouveau  emploi qui est bien rémunéré pour qui pourront satisfaire les besoins de sa famille.
texts.en: Jacques Nyarugabo consults for the Ministry of Health in Rwanda.  He was born in the DRC (Congo).  He is 40 years old and has 8 children between the ages of 20 and 2. His children are in school.  He has a diploma at the AO level in Sociology.  He has been a client of ACB since 2008.  He needs a loan in order to care for his son who has a problem with his spinal column, a friend also had an motorcycle taxi accident.  His goal is to work diligently to pay back the loan and ultimately he wants to find another job with a good salary so he can take care of his family's needs.

loans.use: To pay his son's health expenses

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is 40 years old and married.  He runs a garage with two employees.  He has been operating this business for five years.  He also earns income from farming.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya, Robert has been saving his money and has managed to improve his business.  He hopes to grow his business and employ more people.  

Robert had previously serviced two loans from Faulu Kenya.  He has requested another loan of 60, 000 Kes to buy a welding gas cylinder and a grinder.

loans.use: To buy a welding gas cylinder and a grinder

loans.name: Sisters Of Bong Mines Bridge Group

texts.en:
Lorpu Tokpah, who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Sisters Of Bong Mines Bridge.  She is 44 years old, widowed, and has three children between the ages of 23 and 14 years. She was only able to attend school through 6th grade due to lack of financial support. 

For 11 years, she has been selling rice, flour, oil seasonings, etc. in the Bong Mines Bridge Community in Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 60,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 24,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more oil, rice, flour, etc. to resell.  She describes herself as an honest woman whose goals are to improve her business and continue to educate her children.

In the photo, Debra is inset at lower right because she was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more oil, rice, flour, etc. to resell

loans.name: Mutunga

texts.en:
Mutunga M. is thirty years old.  He is married to a business lady and they do not yet have any children. 

Mutunga's business is located at Mama Ngina, Kizingo Estate in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many tourist attraction sites and its white beaches on the Indian ocean. 

Mutunga does photography, video editing as well as sell films for a living. He has been in this business for eleven years and has managed to provide employment for one person. His major customers are tourists who go to the coast. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is financial constraints. However he works very hard from morning to evening to keep his business doing well.

Mutunga is using this loan of Kes 80,000 to buy a video machine to grow his business. He hopes to own a big studio in future. He describes himself as focused and persuasive.

loans.use: To buy video machine

loans.name: Hakob

texts.en:
Hakob T. is 32 years old. He lives in Lchashen village in the Sevan area. Hakob is married and has two children.

Over the last 10 years, he has been running his own farm where he breeds cows, sheep and chickens.  Hakob’s mother and wife help him in farming and together they work to support their family.  

Hakob’s family work very hard and they hope to increase their farm in the future.  To realize this goal, Hakob is seeking a loan for 1,000,000 AMD to buy some calves for his farm.  This is Hakob's second loan from Nor Horizon.

loans.use: To buy calves for farm

loans.name: God Will Provide Group

texts.en:
Sophia W., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God Will Provide.  She is 62 years old, widowed, and has five children who are between the ages of 45 and 33 years. She was only able to attend school through 2nd grade due to financial constraints. 

For 15 years, she has been selling pepper, palm oil, rice, salt, etc in Garnerville, outside Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 7,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 31,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more pepper, palm oil, rice, salt, charcoal etc. to sell.  She describes herself as a hard-working woman whose goal is to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy pepper, palm oil, rice, salt, etc. to sell

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is 32 years old and married.  For five years, he has been running a Mawa (hair braiding) salon and a barber shop.  In his business, he has employed one person.  

Since he joined Faulu Kenya, George has become more focused in his business.  He hopes to open a very classic salon in the future.  George needs 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy chairs, braids and hair chemicals for his business.

loans.use: To buy chairs, braids and hair chemicals

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase wheat flour, cooking oil and maize flour

loans.name: Progrès Plus Group

texts.en:
Rose is a leader of a community bank named Progrès Plus, which is composed of 12 micro-entrepreneurs united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through IMF HOPE RDC with the goal of developing their businesses. 

Rose, 35, is married. She is a beautician and runs a sewing workshop. She has been in business for many years. She has been operating her business in the western part of Kinshasa. With hard work and good management, and thanks to Hope’s loans, her business has prospered. She makes a profit of about $45 per week. 

Rose’s ambition is to open a hair salon. As she wants to develop her business, she then decided to join one of Hope’s groups in 2009. She is planning to purchase fabrics and cosmetics for her workshop with the next loan. Rose has succeeded with good strategies to build up permanent customers. She always charges her customers fair prices, she knows them well by their names, and she never runs out of stock. 

Rose has five children whose ages are between 3 and 11years old. Three of them attend school.

loans.use: Purchasing fabrics and cosmetics for her workshop in order to increase the working capital

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice K. became a Solio agent in December. Since then, she has been leasing solar chargers to ten members of her community. Beatrice enjoys her Solio while her immediate neighbors are connected to electricity. Their lights cannot be compared to the brightness of her Solio-powered lights. 

Beatrice can also charge her own phone and use her radio while saving on the daily expenses of batteries and mobile-phone charging stations. With the profits from leasing solar chargers and the savings she receives from using her own Solio, she has now decided to open a grocery business. "Long live Solio" is now her motto!

loans.use: To purchase a solar powered kit

loans.name: Faithful Women Group

texts.en:
Jenneh K., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Faithful Women. She is 51 years old, married, and has eight children who are between the ages of 16 and 34 years. She was not able to attend school due to financial constraints. 

For four years, she has been selling pepper, palm oil, rice, salt, etc., in the New Georgia Junction Community outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000-Liberian-Dollars portion of this 25,000-Liberian-Dollars group loan to buy more pepper, palm oil, rice, salt etc.
 
She describes herself as a determined woman whose goals are to improve her business and continue to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more pepper, palm oil, rice, salt, etc.

loans.name: Kuña Marangatu Group

texts.es:
La Sra. Ramona L. fue quien gestionó para que se forme el comité en el lugar donde vive, que es en el Km 20 Acaray barrio San Felipe, en Ciudad del Este. Ella contactó con sus vecinas y amigas para conformar el comité en dicha zona.
El comité se denomina “Kuña Marangatu”,  está en el quinto ciclo, cuenta con 14 integrantes con sus respectivas actividades productivas. Son muy unidas, responsables y solidarias entre ellas.
La sra. Ramona posee una tienda de comestibles, para poder sustentar a su familia día a día, por ello necesita del crédito para adquirir productos más variados y satisfacer mejor a sus clientes. Desea comprar más frutas, verduras, panificados, bebidas, etc.
texts.en:
Ms. Ramona L. is the person who managed to form a committee in the place where she lives, which is in Acaray Km 20 in the San Felipe neighborhood in Ciudad del Este ("City of the East"). She contacted her neighbors and friends to form the committee in that area.  The committee is called "Kuña Marangatu" and is in its fifth loan cycle.  It has 14 members, each with her own livelihood.   They are very united, responsible and supportive of each other.  

Mrs. Ramona has a grocery store to support her family full time.  She needs a loan to purchase a wider variety of products to better satisfy her customers.  She would like to buy more fruits, vegetables, baked goods, beverages, etc.

loans.use: Purchase of fruits, vegetables, baked goods and general food items.

loans.name: United Women Group

texts.en:
Christina G., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called 'United Women'. She is 49 years old, married, and has six children; and the youngest is 16 years old. She was not able to attend school due to financial constraints. 

For 20 years, she has been selling fruits and vegetables in “Chocolate City,” in the suburbs of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 5,000-Liberian-Dollars portion of this 21,000-Liberian-Dollars group loan to buy more fruits and vegetable to resell.

She describes herself as an honest and strong businesswoman whose dreams are to improve her business and build a house.

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetable to resell

loans.name: One Word Unit Group

texts.en:
Osman D. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Osman was born in Yoni village about 28 years ago. He is married to a businesswoman and the couple has one child. For eight years now, Osman has been selling used clothes. 

This is the first loan that Osman and members of his group have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently, improve their living conditions. 

Osman will use his share of the loan (500,000 leones) to expand his business by buying a bale of used clothes to add to his current stock.

loans.use: Buy a bale of used clothes to add to his current stock

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a married woman with six children; four graduated from school while two still attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She operates a poultry business from home, selling to her neighbors and passersby. In addition, she also sells firewood, which contributes to her other source of income. Grace faces major challenges in seasonality and outbreaks of diseases that affect poultry. She hopes to establish a clothing stall in town in the future.

With the 20,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase chicks and feed. Grace decided to work with Yehu because of the availability of sustainable financial services.

loans.use: To purchase chicks and feed

loans.name: Gbotema Ii Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the Gbotema II group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Kenema, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan that these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently, improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Abibatu K.. Abibatu is age 40; she was born in Tongo, a town in eastern Sierra Leone. Currently, she is residing and doing business in Kenema, together with her husband and two children. 

Abibatu sells drinks and has been doing this business for eight years. With the share of this loan, she will expand her business by buying and producing more drinks to sell.

loans.use: Buy and produce more drinks to sell

loans.name: United Women Group

texts.en:
Rose K., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called United Women. She is 28 years old, single, and has four children who are between the ages of 24 months and 10 years. She was only able to attend school through 5th grade due to financial constraints. 

For four years, she has been selling children's toys in the Jamaica Road community in Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 4,000-Liberian-Dollars portion of this 24,000-Liberian-Dollars group loan to buy more bags of toys to resell.

She describes herself as a trustworthy, hard-working and business-minded woman whose dreams are to improve her business and build a house.

loans.use: To buy more bags of toys to resell

loans.name: Zamokuhle Group

texts.en:
Thandi is 58 years old and a widowed mother with seven children between the ages of 19 and 36 years old. She also cares for 10 grandchildren. She runs an art business selling beads and rents traditional clothes from her home in Empangeni, South Africa (KZN). In the photo above, she is seated on the left.

She's been in this business for five years. She also gets income from the government's disability and old age pension support grant. She says the main challenges for her business are customers who do not want pay and difficulty going to get stock since she is disabled. 

She requested this loan through the Women's Development Businesses and KIVA to buy beads for traditional clothes. With the help of WDB and Kiva, she says that the extra income from this loan will help her put her grandchildren through school and have enough food for her family. In the future, she sees her business growing and improving and having a proper room for her material. 

As a disabled women, she would like to thank WDB and Kiva for improving her life by lending her the money. Since 2007, no one wants to lend her money except WDB.

loans.use: To buy beads for traditional cloths

loans.name: Dinah

texts.en:
Dinah is 52 years old and married to Peter S.. They are blessed with five children. She runs a cereals shop, and she has been in this business for three years, earning a monthly income of about $250. She is taking out a loan of 80,000 KES with which she plans to purchase more maize and beans to sell. 

She plans to use the anticipated profit to expand the business. This is her third loan and she paid her previous loans successfully. Her dreams and hopes are to expand her dairy farming business.

loans.use: To buy more maize and beans to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a new oven and additional tools

loans.name: Sunday

texts.en:
Sunday is a married man and has one child who attends school. He lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and transportation. 

He has operated a retail shop business for the past two years, selling to his neighbors and passersby. Sunday faces the major challenges of the high cost of transportation and theft in his business. He hopes to establish a wholesale shop in the future. 

With the 40,000 KES he wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and sacks of sugar. He decided to work with Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and sacks of sugar.

loans.name: Bello Horizonte Group

texts.es:
Para la formación del presente comité, inició los emprendimientos la Sra. Constancia G.,  quien vive en la zona del Km 11 Acaray Asentamiento Bello Horizonte de Ciudad del Este.  Ella contactó con sus vecinas y amigas para formar el comité en la zona.
El comité se denomina “Bello Horizonte”, está en el Sexto Ciclo con  17 integrantes, quienes desarrollan diversas actividades, en la mayoría, comerciales.  Son muy unidas, responsables y solidarias mutuamente.
La sra. Constancia solicita el crédito para poder abastecer mejor su puesto de ventas con frutas y verduras, frescas y saludables, a fin de ofrecer los mejores productos a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Constancia G. initiated the formation of this committee, whose members live in the Acary Km 11 in the Bello Horizante ("Beautiful Horizon") neighborhood in Ciudad del Este ("City of the East").  She contacted her neighbors and friends to form the area committee.  The committee is called "Beautiful Horizon" and is in its sixth loan cycle.  The 17 members undertake a variety of activites, primarily commercial.  They are very united, responsible and supportive of each other.
 
Constancia is requesting a loan to be better able to stock her sales stand with fresh and healthy fruits and vegetables with the goal of providing the best products to her customers.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits (citrus) and vegetables.

loans.name: Florenia

texts.en:
Florenia is a 48-year-old widow who supports her family by operating a grocery store and buying and selling herbal medicines. She lives in the municipality Sta. Fe, Cebu. Florenia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family.  With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Florenia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 12,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,500 to buy more stock for the store so that she can continue to save up for the future expansion of her business.  Florenia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.  

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Alaa

texts.en:
Alaa is a young man from Tulkarem city. Alaa is a National Palestinian Authority employee. He is married and a father of one son.

Alaa, who appears in the picture here in FATEN's branch in Tulkarem, wants to improve his financial situation and save to buy a house one day. Alaa decided to start a grocery store. He started preparing the store that he rented and he needed $3,000 to purchase the rest of the goods to sell.

loans.use: To open a grocery shop

loans.name: Thuthuka Group

texts.en:
Beatrice is 52 years old and single with four children, two of whom attend school. She also cares for one relative in Stanger, KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. She sells clothing and pinafores ("aprons"). In the photo above, she is raising her hand in the center of the group.

She has been in this business for two years and does not have employees. With this loan, she plans to purchase more clothing stock and hopes to hire an additional employee in the future. She also seeks to improve her life and her business. Fortunately, she does not experience many challenges in her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothing

loans.name: Josephat Ekwam

texts.en:
Josephat Ekwam E. is a gentle man of twenty-two years who is married to Rhoda Payo, and together they have two children. They live in Eldoret town where his wife runs a grocery store. In the same area Josephat sells goat meat from place to place. He has been in this business for five years now and gets a monthly income of about $75.

This will be Josephat's first loan from KADET LTD. He plans to diversify his business and use the entire loan to buy poultry to raise and sell later at a profit. With the income that he will get, he plans to buy goats for slaughter and later sell the meat. 

In the future, Josephat wants to educate his children to the highest level and also become a big retailer of goat meat in Eldoret.

loans.use: To buy poultry for resale

loans.name: Everlyne Vugudza

texts.en:
Everlyne L. is a 28-year-old enterprising lady from the county of Kakamega in western Kenya. She is single and supports only herself at the moment. 

She is a hardworking business lady who buys and supplies Irish potatoes in Kakamega town. She has been doing this business for the last two years and she makes a monthly income of approximately $240. 

Everlyne is taking her second loan from KADET LTD, which she will use to buy thirty bags of potatoes to sell. She will use the anticipated profits to plow back into the business. Her hope and dream is to become a major distributor of Irish potatoes to higher institutions of learning and to hotels.

loans.use: To buy 30 bags of Irish potatoes to sell.

loans.name: In Jesus Name Group

texts.en:
Marie P., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called "In Jesus Name".  She is 57 years old, married, and has four children who are between the ages of 32 and 38. She was unable to attend school due to financial constraints. 

For ten years, she has been operating a mini-restaurant in Darquee Town outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 4,000 LRD portion of this 20,000 LRD group loan to buy more bags of rice, oil, fish, meat, onions, tomatoes, seasonings etc.

She describes herself as a successful woman whose dream is to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, oil, fish, meat, onions, tomato, seasonings etc

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa is a married woman who lives in Bantayan, Cebu. She earns her living by operating three business ventures:  fishing, buying and selling dried fish and a sari-sari (general) store. Her husband Rodulfo who is 37 years old, works as a fishermen to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have four children who are 12 to 20 years old. Rosa joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1997 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 19 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rosa has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 27,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 24,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 20th loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,500 to buy a new engine for her fishing boat so that she can continue to save up for the future expansion of her business. Rosa is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org

loans.use: To purchase a new engine for her fishing boat

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes A. is 40 years old from Migori town. She is married to Elisha and they have two children who are in school. She has a business of selling delicacies locally known as "Kaimati" (sweet dumplings). People like them for breakfast and they take them with tea. 

Agnes is applying for her fourth loan from KADET LTD to enable her to buy baking flour and cooking oil to add to her stock. She earns a monthly income of about $250. She is hopeful that the loan will boost her business. Her dream is to be able to open a big hotel in the future.

loans.use: To buy cooking flour and oil.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 41-year-old single woman living with one parent. She is from Lebanon. She has owned an accessories and perfume shop since 1988. She is the only income provider for the family. She obtained her first Kiva loan and was a very good client with payments made on time.

Today, she is requesting to borrow $1500 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to increase her store’s inventory of accessories and perfumes.  She notes that the diversity of her merchandise will attract more clients and therefore increase her sales. In the future, she is planning to add women's bags and clothes to her shop.

loans.use: To increase her store’s inventory

loans.name: Dolly Eugenia

texts.es:
Trabajar la confección a terceros es el oficio que desempeña Dolly Eugenia M. T., quien a muy temprana edad aprendió a coser al lado de su hermana. La falta de oportunidades laborales sumado a su poca preparación y las dificultades económicas por la que atravesaban ella y su esposo,  la obligaron a iniciar su propio negocio. 

Actualmente Dolly confecciona prendas a terceros lo que le ha permitido contribuir para cubrir los gastos del hogar y hacer más llevadera su situación. 

Dolly necesita de un préstamo para comprar insumos como telas e hilos y así cumplir con los pedidos de sus clientes que cada vez son mayores.
texts.en:
Sewing for other people is what Dolly Eugenia M. T. does for a living. She and her sister learned how to sew at an early age. Dolly started her own business due to the shortage of job opportunities as well as her lack of preparation and the financial difficulties that she and her husband have faced.

Dolly currently manufactures clothes for other people. This enables her to contribute toward the household expenses and make her situation more tolerable. She needs a loan to buy supplies such as fabrics and thread so that she can fulfill the orders of her customers that are becoming overdue.

loans.use: Purchase fabrics & thread

loans.name: Desideria

texts.en: Desideria lives in the municipality of Sta. Fe, in the island of Bantayan, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a shell crafting business.  Her common-law husband Andy, who is 32 years old, works as a trisikad driver to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  She has four children who are 6 months to 13 years old.  Desideria joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past seven loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Desideria has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 25,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her eighth loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,000 to use as additional capital for the business so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children.  Desideria is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: To fund the operations of her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase an electricity generator to run the machines used in the workshop

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther M. is a married lady. Her husband works for a security firm and they have three children between 2 and 9 years old, who they hope to provide a good education through the university level. 

Esther's business is located at Vikwatani in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is in the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for many tourist sites, including white-sand beaches on the Indian Ocean. 

Esther has a tailoring shop where she makes clothes for local people. She has been in this business for four years. She says the business is profitable and the major challenge she has is her financial constraints. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy materials to expand her business and meet the demands of her customers. She hopes to be a market leader in this type of business in future. She describes herself as determined and open-minded.

loans.use: To buy materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase textiles and beads

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Rose G. is 48 years old, married to John, and they have four children who are between the ages of 13 and 25. They live in the Mumat area in Sondu.

Rose runs a restaurant business and is applying for her first loan, which will enable her to buy food ingredients like cooking oil, flour, sugar and rice to add to her stock. Rose is optimistic that her business will do better after getting the loan. She earns a monthly income of approximately $375 

Her dream is to see her business grow to greater heights and to be able to employ a few people to help her run it.

loans.use: To buy cooking oil, flour, sugar and rice to add to her stock.

loans.name: Siyethemba Group

texts.en:
Carol is 53 years old and married, with 4 children between the ages of 10 and 25 years. Only one of her children attends school. She runs a clothing business in Mtubatuba in South Africa (KZN). In the photo she is in a green shirt raising her hand.

She has been in this business for 5 years, selling new clothes and hiring, or renting clothes to customers at her home. She also earns income from  a government disability grant. She says that the main challenges to her business are customers who do not pay on time. She requested this loan through WDB and Kiva to buy new clothes. She adds that the extra income from this loan will help her buy furniture for her family and extend her home. In the future, she would like to own a big shop in town.

loans.use: To buy new clothes and fabric

loans.name: Dickson

texts.en:
Dickson is 31 years old and married to Getrude Kiprop, who produces some additional income to the family. They have four children between the ages of 1 and 11. He has been farming for eleven years, planting assorted fruits and vegetables which he sells later to his customers. He earns a monthly profit of approximately $208.

He requesting a loan of 60,000 KES which he plans to use to buy watermelon seeds, fungicides and insecticides, and to plow and also to pay labor. He plans to save the anticipated profit to pay school fees for his children,

loans.use: To upgrade his farming of fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim is from Al Bayader.  He is a 37-year-old single man who owns a small shop where he repairs car exhaust systems. Ibrahim started his business many years ago and he applying for a loan of JD1800 to purchase new equipment to enlarge his project. His aspiration is to develop his project further,  hiring more employees and increasing his income.

loans.use: To purchase new equipment to develop his project

loans.name: Thembeka Group

texts.en:
Fikile is 42 years old and married with two children, ages 7 and 20. She runs a small spazza (or "shop") in Mtubatuba, South Africa. She is standing at the front in the photo above, raising her hand.

She's been in this business for five years, selling airtime, cool drinks and chickens from her home. She also earns income from the government’s child support grant. She says that the main challenge to her business is that the customers do not pay on time.

She requested this loan through Women’s Development Business and KIVA to buy more airtime and chickens to sell. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her send her children to school. In five years time she would like to build a new shelter for her business. 

She appreciates WDB and Kiva very much.

loans.use: To buy airtime and chickens to sell

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.en:
Benjamin M. is twenty-seven years old, married to a businesswoman, and they have one nine-year-old child to whom they hope to provide a good education to the university level. Benjamin's business is located in a busy market in Kakamega, which is the region in Kenya known for the production of sugar canes, also known as the sugar belt region. 

He sells music discs and tapes to the local people. He has been running this business for four years now and has one employee. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is financial constraints. 

He is using his loan of 40,000 KES to buy more music discs and tapes to grow his business and meet the demands of his customers. He hopes to be a wholesaler in the future. He describes himself as a very visionary man.

loans.use: Music discs and tapes

loans.name: Claudia Patricia

texts.es:
En las montañas de una vereda de Sonsón Antioquia en Colombia, vive Claudia Claudia patricia C., una jóven que a sus 29 años de edad decidió desde hace algunos años aportar para cubrir los gastos de la familia con su propio trabajo. 

Fue así como motivada por la ilusión de mejorar su calidad de vida, la de su esposo y la de su hija inició con la confección de prendas, oficio que aprendió desde hace algunos años. Su esposo se dedica a las labores del campo mientras que ella además de ser ama de casa y madrugar desde muy temprano confecciona sobre pedido las prendas de sus vecinos y conocidos, así mismo se las ingenia para elaborar muñecos de diferentes estilos. 

Para mejorar su negocio, Claudia necesita de un crédito para comprar materia prima para elaborar algunas manualidades que le permitirán mejorar sus ingresos.
texts.en:
Claudia Patricia C. lives along the Sonsón Antioquia Road in the mountains of Colombia. She is a young woman who is 29 years of age. A few years ago, she decided to cover the family expenses through her own work.

Motivated by the hope of improving her family’s quality of life, Claudia started producing garments. She learned this skill a few years ago. Her husband works in the fields while she performs her duties as a homemaker and seamstress. In the early morning hours, she begins sewing based on the orders she receives from neighbors and acquaintances. In addition, she makes dolls in different styles.

To improve her business, Claudia needs a loan to buy materials for producing some of her handicrafts. This will enable her to improve her earnings.

loans.use: Purchase materials

loans.name: Zenon Ariel

texts.es:
El cliente tiene 23 años vive en el municipio de entre ríos del trópico de Cochabamba, empezó a trabajar a los 16 años en las empresas petroleras como sereno, posteriormente paso a realizar trabajos como ayudante.

Zenón  se independizo a muy temprana edad, vivía en alquiler, pero no le alcanzaba la plata que ganaba, ya que los contratos eran temporales de dos a cuatro meses, nada más, pero ahorro privándose de muchas cosas, se compró una motocicleta para  trabajar como moto taxista, actualmente sigue realizando este servicio.

El crédito que solicita es para comprar un terreno agrícola, que has sido su sueño de toda su vida, ahora con el crédito está a punto de cumplirse, y de esa manera, también trabajar en la agricultura, y seguir creciendo.
texts.en:
Zenón is 23 years old and lives in the municipality of Cochabamba, between two tropical rivers. He started working at the age of 16 for a petroleum company as a night watchman, and later as an assistant.

Zenón became independent at an early age. He lived in a rental property, but he could not afford it on his salary since he was hired on temporary contracts that lasted between two to four months. However, he was able to accumulate a significant amount in savings which he used to buy a motorcycle so that he could work as a motorcycle taxi driver. He currently provides this service.

The loan he is requesting will be used to buy a plot of farmland, which has always been his dream in life. Once he has the loan secured, he will be at the point in time when his dream can become reality. Zenón will be able to work as a farmer and continue growing.

loans.use: Purchase a plot of land so that he can begin farming

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 48-year-old widowed woman from Lebanon. She lives with her two young children. She started her own business out of her home in 2008. She is specialized in producing paper bags. Despite her age, she must work hard each day to satisfy her family needs. She obtained her first Kiva loan and she was a reliable client with punctual payments.

Today, she is requesting to borrow $1400 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase a bag stapler so that she can proceed with her business operation faster. In the future, she hopes to further expand her business and continue her work properly to earn superior income for her family.

loans.use: to purchase a bag stapler

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Operating capital to start a restaurant

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en: Mohammad is a 26-year-old married man with two children. He owns his own barber shop, and in order to expand he is requesting a loan of 1,000 JOD to purchase new equipment to develop his professional capacity. His future plans are to expand his current shop which would eventually increase his family income.

loans.use: To purchase new equipment for his barber shop

loans.name: Oscar Rolando

texts.es:
