loans.name: Sombo's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of 11 members who reside in Daeum Kor village in Kandal Province. Sombo M., born in 1971, is the village bank president selected by the other members, all of whom hope to increase their income through this loan in order to improve their families' living standards.

Sombo M. earns her living making pillows for sale. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it and so is requesting a loan to buy additional material to make more pillows to sell.

loans.use: To buy more material to make pillows for sale.

loans.name: Esterlita

texts.en:
Esterlita G. is from the village of Linabu, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 63 years old. Esterlita is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Esterlita owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling seafood products  including fish such as sardines & salmon in the local community. Esterlita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Esterlita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Esterlita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Esterlita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell such as mackerel & sardines. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Esterlita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell such as mackerel & sardines

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey A., born in 1968, lives in Kokir Thum village in Kandal Province, where she owns a plot of land upon which she grows rice. Srey would like to grow rice during the dry season but lacks sufficient funds to do so. She is therefore requesting a loan to buy fertilizers, pesticides, and gasoline to support her rice field.

Srey supplements her living by making Khmer cakes for sale. Her husband, Mr. Norng Sophat, is a laborer who is able to earn a small salary to help support his family, and also helps in his wife's farming.

This couple has four children, three attending the local school, while the youngest is only four years old. Srey's husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, pesticides, and gasoline to support her rice field.

loans.name: Alma

To make a living, Alma owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods & beverages in the local community. Alma has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

loans.name: Ben's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four members, they are located in Chanlak village in Kandal province. 

Mrs. Ben M., born in 1942, has been selected as the group leader by the other members. Mrs. Ben M. is widow with a child who is a security guard in a private company. 

She is a farmer who owns a plot of land that she uses to grow rice. But she doesn’t have enough money to support her farming, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seeds, fertilizers, pesticides, gasoline, and a pesticide sprayer.

loans.name: Chak's Group

texts.en:
Four members are forming this group loan. They are located in Svay Prey village in Kandal province. Mrs. Chak S., a married woman born in 1980,  was selected to be the group leader by the other members. 

She is a farmer who owns a field that she uses to grow rice. Her husband, Mr. Kek Thoeun, is a farm laborer who is able to earn a small salary to help support his family. This couple has three children. Two are attending the local school and one is too young to study or work. 

With their occupations, they still earn less than enough income to support the family. So in order to increase income to improve the family's living conditions, Mrs. Chak S. would like to ask for a loan to buy chickens for breeding. The rest of the loan she would use to buy zinc for her house roof.

loans.use: To buy chickens for breeding

Now her house is old, so she would like to ask for a loan to add to her savings to fix up her house.

loans.name: Toch

texts.en:
Mrs. Toch S., was born in 1974 and is a villager who lives in Anlong Ta Sek Leu village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land which she uses to grow rice and corn for a living. Aside from farming, she also earns her living by selling groceries in the local village. With her occupations, she is able to earn a small income to support her family. 

Mrs. Toch S. is a widow with two children who are students in the school. They also help their mother in farming. 
 
Currently, her house has a big puddle, so she would like to ask for a loan to add to her savings to buy soil to fill her land.

loans.use: To add her savings to buy soil to fill her land

loans.name: Nieva

texts.en:
“We cannot make good news out of bad practice,” Edward R. Murrow said. Nieva S., 52, makes sure there is good news about her business to tell about. Nieva reached only elementary school; now, she is running her own business. She is married to a driver named Jose and is a mother to three children. Their family resides in Caloocan City, Metro Manila.

It is Nieva’s business to deliver daily news to her community by making the local newspapers more accessible to them. She is a newspaper dealer earns around Php12,500 every month. This job is something Nieva really enjoys as she gets hold of the daily news first and is able to witness immediate reactions of her fellow community members upon the sight of the news for the day.

To help her sustain her business, Nieva is borrowing the amount of Php 50,000. The money will be used mainly to order newspapers; part of the money will go to pay other bills. Nieva also mentioned saving up to be able to establish another personal business. This loan will go far toward enabling her to get to that dream and make it happen soon.

Nieva admits her work is tiring, but emphasizes that she enjoys doing it no matter how exhausting it can be. She makes certain that she implements good practice to offer good service to her community. She desires for more success to her business, so that she can be able to help others, especially her family.

As a CCT Community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro finance loans.

loans.use: ordering newspapers

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is a married woman who lives in San Carlos City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a sari-sari (general) store, a carenderia (a local eatery) and a livestock business. Her husband Reneboy, who is 41 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities. They have three children who are 11 to 22 years old. Two of the children work and the other one is currently going to school. Teresita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 20 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Teresita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 14,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 7,200, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 21st loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000 to fund her business operations so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children and for family needs. Teresita is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org

loans.use: To fund her business operations

loans.name: Yi's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of seventeen members located in Kbal Kaoh Touch village in Kandal province. Mrs. Yi C., who was born in 1956, is the village bank president selected by the other members.

She and her husband, Mr. Chhoem Lim, are farmers who own a plot of land on which they grow rice and different vegetables to help support their family. They also earn a small income by making baskets for sale. 

This couple has five children: two are workers, two are waitresses in a restaurant and one is a laborer in a bakery shop. Since their children work so far from home, Mrs. Yi C. would like to ask for a loan to purchase a motorcycle for her children's transportation.

loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle for her children to commute to work

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Standing out and making a difference is hard to do, but Rosita A., 47, is determined to do so. Rosita reached only high school and is married to Joselin, an electrician. Being a community partner of CCT, Rosita applies her learning in entrepreneurship to her business. Together, Joselin and Rosita raise their three children.

Rosita owns a sari-sari (variety) store located near their house. There she outshines other sari-sari stores in the vicinity by providing quality products at an affordable price. She makes sure her stock is fresh and worth every centavo of her customers’ money. Monthly Rosita earns a net income of Php 3,900.

Standing out requires maximum effort, and Rosita needs help to make her business stand out. She decided to borrow Php 24,000 to help her grow her business. With this she will buy more canned goods, noodles, soap, toothpaste and other household essentials. She believes that increasing the quantity of her products will affect the profitability of her store and add up to savings for her. 

A usual problem shared by Rosita with other sari-sari store owners is the difficulty in collecting payments from neighbors who do not pay their bills. Cash flow is very important for Rosita as the store is one main way of financing the studies of her children. That is why Rosita never gives up despite the problems and reaches for her dream of growing her store into a bigger enterprise.

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro finance loans.

loans.use: the replenishment of products

loans.name: Renilda

texts.en:
One famous quote says, “If you fail to plan, you plan to fail”.  Renilda F., or Taring as she is called by her friends, makes sure she plans well so as to have a good future ahead of her. Still single at 26 years of age, Taring runs her own business as she receives continuous entrepreneurial training from CCT as a community partner. Taring finished high school and presently resides in Caloocan City.

Taring owns a sari-sari (variety) store near her home. On a daily basis, she competes with other sari-sari stores in the community and makes sure her regular customers will keep buying goods from her while she continues attracting other neighbors to buy from her store. Taring has been in this business for five years now. She earns around 10,700 PHP a month.

To help her grow her business, Taring needs a loan amount of 10,000 PHP.  She will use this loan to purchase quality products which her customers are looking for. She makes sure that her store shelves will not lack any essential product which her neighbors need, and so she plans to buy more canned goods, soft drinks, and other grocery items. Taring believes that this loan will raise her sari-sari store above her competitors.

Competition is something one cannot and should not avoid. Making the most out of it, Taring is using competition to push her business to grow. This is important for her as she strives to reach her dream of having a good, well-provided for family of her own someday.

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase quality grocery items for her store

loans.name: Marivonne

texts.en:
Being connected is something that Marivonne L. values deeply, whether it is being connected with family members, or with business acquaintances. Yvonne, as she is called by her friends, is a college graduate.  At 38, she runs her own business, serves her husband Edgardo who works abroad, and mothers two children who both study in elementary school.

Marivonne is in the business of buying and selling merchandise. What she sells often is food, which is a basic need of people everywhere. She looks for the kind of food that is a daily essential and that which suits the tastes of her customers. With this entrepreneurial effort she earns a net income of 9,800 PHP.

To help her continue the operation of her business, Marivonne would like to request a loan of 14,000 PHP. With the loan and the learning she receives from CCT as a community partner, she will grow her business. She will purchase frozen food, cookies, and some canned goods, and strategize on how to get as many satisfied customers as she can.

At present, Marivonne deals with the problem of collecting payments from her customers. Nevertheless, she believes that good relational skills will enable her to solve this issue with her business connections. She continually holds on to the strength and favor God gives her to make her life better, such as having an expanding business with its own official commercial space. A sweeter success that she aims for is to make their living sustainable enough that her husband would not have to work abroad. Then, her desire of a family that stays together will be fulfilled. 

As a CCT community partner, Marivonne faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase frozen food and cookies for sale

loans.name: Restituto

texts.en:
It feels good to exceed other people’s expectations. But more than doing it for the goal of feeling good, Restituto R., 27, does it for his family’s future. 

Restituto has been educated to high school level and is married to Mechelle, who is a devoted housewife and mother to their children, who now study in school. The family resides in Binondo, Manila.

Restituto runs a sari-sari (general) store with the help of his wife. Aside from common products such as canned goods and instant noodles, he also sells ice, which is sought after in the hot weather. Mineral water is also part of the list of items for sale. The store is relatively easy to manage because Restituto and his family also live there. Monthly, he earns around Php12,000.

To help him grow his business, Restituto decided to borrow Php14,000. He will use this to buy more products to fill his shelves. He will boost his selling of ice and water as the summer is fast approaching. With this loan he believes he can be more profitable and earn additional money to save and use for future opportunities.

Restituto lacks the capital for expansion. He believes that this is a great challenge, as many other sari-sari stores in the vicinity are also competing for more regular customers. Restituto wants to make sure his regular customers will remain loyal and also wants to reach out to more potential customers. He wants to change the expectation that sari-sari stores are meant to stay small, because being able to expand his business will enable him to provide quality education for his children. At the end of the day, it will still be for his family.

As a CCT community partner, he faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of god he receives.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of god, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

texts.en:
Amelita is a married woman who lives in Cadiz, Negros Occidental.  She earns her living by operating a sari-sari (general) store.  Her husband Anthony, who is 33 years old, works as a tricycle driver to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have four children who are 2 to 9 years old. This time, for her 17th loan, she is borrowing PHP 14,000 to purchase more stock to sell so that she can continue to save up for future house improvements.  Amelita is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.  

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe is a married woman who lives in Danao City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a general store, a pig fattening business and an e-loading business. Her husband Rey, who is 33 years old, works as a security guard to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities. Fe joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2010 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past two loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Fe has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 9,800, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her third loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000 to buy more stock for resale so that she can continue to save up for future business improvement and home repairs. Fe is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena B. is from the village of Barangay 25, Pandan, Gingoog City. She is 50 years old. Magdalena is married and has 2 children. To make a living, Magdalena owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from making and selling a variety of meals like "adobo" and "afritada" in the local community. She also runs her retail store selling assorted products. Magdalena has been engaged in her businesses for over 6 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Magdalena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Magdalena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional ingredients and additional  working capital. Magdalena is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make meals for sale. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Magdalena from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Yodgora

texts.ru: Юсупова Ёдгора проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 52 года. Замужем, имеет одного ребенка. Сын находится на заработках в России. Сама Ёдгора занимается торговлей. У нее имеется магазин, где она вместе с мужем продает продукты питания. Уже год как она занимается этим видом деятельности. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота. Она хочет расширить свою деятельность и в будущем открыть еще один магазин.
texts.en: Yodgora Y. lives in the Yavan district.  She is 52 years old, married and has one child.  Her son is working in Russia.  Yodgora is involved in retail sales.  She has a store, where her husband and she sell food products.  She has been involved in this business for one year.  She is requesting this loan in order to increase product turnover.  She wants to expand her business and open another store in the future.

loans.use: Increasing product turnover

loans.name: Pech

texts.en:
Mrs. Pech was born in 1965. She is married to Mr. Vanna Naun (pictured with her).  They are farmers who rent a small piece of land where they can grow rice. They sell part of their rice yield and keep the rest to support their family.

They have some problems with the rice field because the soil is infertile, the field is far from an irrigation system, and it has a lot of insects.  To improve their rice production, Mrs. Pech would like to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, gasoline, and pesticide. She is the mother of five children:  Three are laborers and the others attend the local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, gasoline, and pesticide

loans.name: Silvestre

texts.en:
Silvestre A. is from the village of San Miguel, Gingoog City. He is 31 years old. Silvestre is separated from his spouse and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Silvestre owns & operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing "motorela" or "habal-habal" (motorcycle taxi) services to local community members. Silvestre has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Silvestre joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Silvestre has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. Silvestre is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the service. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Silvestre from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

texts.en:
Juanita is a married woman who lives in Valladolid, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a vegetable farming and vending business. Her husband Samuel, who is 45 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living.  They have two children who are 23 and 25 years old. Juanita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past seven loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Juanita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her eighth loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000 to fund her vegetable farming business so that she can continue to save up for future house repair and house improvement. Juanita is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Bav

texts.en:
Bav S., pictured here with her daughter and grandson, is a 44-year-old farmer who lives in the province of Kompong Cham. Bav S. is married to Kour Chheil, age 46. Bav S. and her husband work together in the farming business.  They have five children: One is married and the other four are single. Two of her children work in a garment factory. 

In addition to the farm, Bav S. owns a wooden kiosk next to her house for extra income. Bav S. is looking for a loan to use toward purchasing fertilizer and gasoline. With the rest of the funds, she will buy piglets for breeding. From this, she will be able to improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, and gasoline. And with the rest fund, she will use to buy piglets for breeding.

texts.en:
Analyn V. lives in the village of San Jose, Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 23 years old, married and has four young children. For the last five years, she has made a living by running a specialized retail store where she sells bananas and coconuts. She makes about 3,000 PHP a month from her work.

Earlier this year, Analyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She is applying for a loan, her first, for PHP 5,000 to buy more coconuts to sell. She plans to use the additional income she earns to continue improving and expanding her business.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
E., 37, lives in Silang, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Romeo E., who drives a vehicle for a living, and has one child who is in school. She dreams of educating her child through the university level because she believes that a college diploma is the best gift parents can leave to their children.

Erlinda earns about PHP 2,000 a week by selling clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products, including Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk and the Marikina Shoe Exchange. She charges less that catalogs and will use this loan to secure orders for her customers. She believes she will succeed, and attends our meetings to share success stores and sales tips every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the gospel, build social capital, and pay back microfinance loans.

Она предоставляет услугу, занимается шитьем национальных платьев. В основном она покупает разные ткани и шьет национальные платья для молодых девушек на праздник "Навруз" (праздник весны). Bunafsha has a secondary education.  She provides a service by sewing national dresses.  She primarily buys various fabrics and makes national dresses for young women for the Navruz holiday (holiday of the spring).  She has been involved in this type of business for five years.  Bunafsha is requesting this loan for the purchase of fabrics.

loans.name: Gloria

Gloria A. lives in the village of Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 55 years old, married and has three grown children. texts.en:
Anna Marie M. is from the village of Tagpako, Gingoog City. She is 31 years old. Anna Marie is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Anna Marie owns & operates a business making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling Filipino delicacies, like sinigang na bangus (stewed milkfish in tamarind) & gisadong pancit (shrimp and chicken wonton soup) in the local community. Anna Marie has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Anna Marie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anna Marie is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients, like vegetables, needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Anna Marie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
An ordered life is something Lourdes P., 49, yearns to have for her whole family.  She is doing all she can to achieve just that. One effort to reach this goal is to have a means of sustainability. Thus, Lourdes joined CCT* as a community partner, and, with the entrepreneurial learning she gains there, she is able to run her own small business. Lourdes is married to Rolando, who is a water tender. They have a child who is now in high school.

Lourdes directly sells beauty products, such as local brands M.S.E., Natasha, and Board Walk,  and other accessories to friends, neighbors, and business connections. She also sells silver jewelry chosen for her clients' tastes. Rolando, on the other hand, makes money by delivering gallons of water to the homes of fellow community members with the use of his side car. Their monthly family income reaches around Php10,000.

To help grow her business, Lourdes decided to ask for a Php14,000 loan. She intends to use this loan money to purchase her own stock of products, accessories, and jewelry items for sale. She needs enough money on hand to buy her customers' orders even before their initial payments. The loan money, Lourdes says, increases her capacity to earn and helps to augment the needs of her family.

One major problem she faces is the fact that some customers do not pay on time. Lourdes takes the responsibility of paying for the sold item. But Lourdes is willing and ready to face whatever challenge lies ahead, just for their lives to be sustained and be in order. She commits herself to financing the studies of her child until she sees this child graduate from college. She also desires to renovate their house, and all these efforts will depend largely on the growth of her business.


*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Restocking inventory

Roselyn has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

Roselyn is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients, like eggs & flour, needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Roselyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Muhayo

texts.ru: Убайдова Мухайё жительница Яванского района. Ей 29 лет. Вдова, имеет двоих детей. Живет вместе с родителями и с семьей брата. Брат работает строителем. Сама Мухайё работает в ателье, она занимается шитьем национальных платьев. Этим видом деятельности занимается более 5 лет. Кредит берет для покупки материалов.
texts.en: Muhayo U. lives in the Yavan district.  She is 29 years old, a widow and has two children.  She lives with her parents and her brother's family.  Her brother is a construction worker.  Mahayo works at an atelier.  She is involved in sewing national dresses.  She has been in this business for over 5 years.  She is requesting this loan for the purchase of materials.

loans.use: Purchase of materials

loans.name: Edielyn

texts.en:
Being a new player in a different playing field brings on a lot of challenges. This is what Edielyn T., 20, experiences both in her personal life and in her business. Edielyn did not reach college. At present, she is a community partner with CCT*, a wife to 20-year old, Johnny, who works as a pedicab driver, and a young mother to two little children. Their family lives in Baseco, Manila.

Edielyn cooks and sells jampong for the neighborhood. This gives her a source of income, along with her sari-sari (variety) store, where she hangs packets of shampoo and toothpaste, and stores candies and biscuits in transparent containers for the customers to see. The store is an extension of their home, so Edielyn can manage it while taking care of her kids. Edielyn has been in this business for two years.  Monthly, she earns Php20, 000 on average.

Knowing that she needs financial aid to help her grow her business, she decided to  borrow Php10, 000. She will use this to buy ingredients for making jampong and for buying grocery items for her store. She can see that more products on display will encourage customers to buy at her store. The loan, she affirms, is a big help, not only to her business but also to her growing family.

Her challenges include having customers who do not regularly pay their debts.  As a young wife and mom, it is hard to manage both home and business. But she is determined not to give up, knowing that she is responsible for not just her own life, but for the life of her family.


*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Restocking inventory

loans.name: Um

texts.en:
Um S. is a 49 year-old man who lives in the province of Kompong Tom. Um S. sells beds in and around his community. His product is made mostly from wood.  Usually, he can earn a daily income  of about $5.60 per day. His wife is a local rice farmer who makes a profit of approximately $1.60 each day. The couple has five children:  Three are single and the other two are married. 

Um S.'s income is low because his motorcycle is too small to carry beds.  That is why Um S. has decided to ask for a loan of $1200 to buy a trailer to connect to his motorcycle so that he can use it to transport more beds than before.

loans.use: To buy a trailer for his motorcycle to increase the number of beds he can transport.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa is a 49-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a buy and sell fashion accessories business. She lives in Valladolid, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2001 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her buy and sell fashion accessories business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 15,000. Teresa is borrowing PHP 12,000 to purchase more stock to sell.   This will be her 15th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Teresa aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. To make a living, Pedro owns a business  operating a specialized store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling seafood products, including sardines & milkfish, in the local community. Pedro has been engaged in his business for over 7 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Pedro joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Pedro has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Pedro is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish, like mackerel & sardines, to sell . This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Pedro from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business.

loans.name: Antonio

texts.en:
Antonio N., 32, knows that little beginnings can lead to great things. He reached only high school, but now he is running his own business and aspiring to more. The lessons of entrepreneurship and weekly Bible fellowships in CCT* enabled him to reach this point in his life. He is husband to Rosalinda, a water tender, and father to four children who are now in school. Their family currently resides in Baseco, Manila.

Antonio’s primary business is operating a pedicab ( a bicycle with sidecar used for public transportation).  He also sees opportunities in selling biscuits and water. Though small, his business has good potential for growth. He buys biscuits in bulk and sells them to neighbors and friends. He also uses his side car to deliver gallons of water to members of the community. His business has been going on for five years . Antonio works hard to offer only the best service to his customers.

To further help him grow his small businesses, Antonio is asking for a loan of Php14, 000. He plans to use this to purchase more items for repacking and selling. Part of the money will also go to the maintenance of his side car.  

Unpaid debts of customers contribute to his worries. Nevertheless, he believes that God is the solution to all these problems, and that his faith will see him through. He prays that his business will prosper and his children will all finish their studies as they grow up to become good, responsible citizens. 


*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Maintenance of sidecar units and additional stock to sell.

loans.name: Esterlina

texts.en:
Esterlina V. is from the village of Tagpako, Gingoog City. She is 38 years old. Esterlina is single. To make a living, Esterlina owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) shop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products, such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods & beverages, in the local community. Esterlina has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Esterlina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Esterlina is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell, like canned goods & biscuits. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Esterlina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase additional products, like canned goods & biscuits, to sell

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina D. is from the village of Libon, Gingoog City. She is 55 years old. Angelina is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Angelina owns & operates a business in which the main source of income comes primarily from buying and selling timber & wood & wood-related products. She also makes and sells charcoal.  Angelina has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Angelina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Angelina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Angelina is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional stock of timber. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Angelina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of timber

loans.name: Kurbongul

texts.ru: Одинаева Курбонгул жительница Яванского района. Ей 39 лет. Она замужем, имеет 5 детей. Муж находится в России на заработках. Сама она занимается растениеводством. При доме имеет участок земли, где выращивает овощи для продажи. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже год. Кредит берет для закупа семян и минеральных удобрений.
texts.en: Kurbongul O. lives in the Yavan district.  She is 39 years old, married and has 5 children.  Her husband is working in Russia.  Kurbongul is involved in agriculture.  She has a land plot by her house, where she grows vegetables for sale.  She has been involved in this business for one year.  She is requesting this loan for the purchase of seeds and mineral fertilizers.

loans.use: Purchase of seeds and mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Liza

texts.en:
In life, all things are possible. Liza Q., 39, banks on this optimistic truth and applies it to her life. She reached only high school, but being a community partner of CCT* gives her the hope of running a profitable business.  She is one of CCT's Community Servant Leaders as a volunteer. Liza is married to Roberto, who operates a tricycle (taxi). Their family of four children lives in Binondo, Manila.

Liza does direct selling. She orders products from the local beauty brands, Personal Collection and M. S. E., based on the preferences of her customers. Also, she sells vaioius other items, from diapers to eggs. Her 16-year old daughter helps her with the business.  Liza has been doing this for 15 years. She earns a monthly income of Php10,000.

To help her grow her business, she has applied for a Php30, 000 loan. She needs this to purchase additional stock.

The difficulty of collecting payments for the ordered products is Liza’s primary business concern. She also worries about the maintenance of the tricycle. Liza prays for a breakthrough in the growth of her businesses. She believes that, like many things, this is possible.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase stock ordered in advance by customers

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene G., 55, values security very much and desires it in her life, both in her business and personal life. Irene was not able to get to high school, but the entrepreneurial learning she gains from CCT* as a community partner enables her to run her business well. She is married to Reynaldo, a security guard, and they have two children. Their family lives in Baseco, Manila.

Irene makes money from collecting scrap materials, and contributes to the effort of managing waste in the community. She has been in the business for six years. She also has a food stall, at which she and her helpers prepare breakfast for community members in a rush in the morning. Every month Irene makes around Php9,000.

To help her grow her business, she asks for Php26,000. This will be a big help to her as it will allow her to purchase needed materials for efficient functioning .  More than anything, she desires a peaceful life for each member of her family and security both in her business and in her family.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Restocking inventory

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Sam Y., 53, is skilled at making furniture.  His main activity is selling rattan cupboards and beds. He sells these products, which he and his wife make at home or they order from other rattan weavers who live in the village. 

Sam Y. and his wife have three children, one of whom is married. Two of their daughters are employed: One has been working in the sewing industry for years and the other is a rattan weaver. In order to make additional income, Sam Y. is asking for a loan from Kiva to buy planks so that he can go on making beds for sale.

loans.use: To buy planks to make beds for sale.

loans.name: Remelina

texts.en:
Family ranks first in the life of Remelina U., 35. She reached college and uses all she learned from there and from the entrepreneurial training she receives as a community partner in CCT* to boost her business. She is married to Roy, the driver of a delivery truck. They have two children, who are both in elementary school. Their family came from the province of Bohol and now resides in Baseco, Manila.

Last year, Remelina saw a good business opportunity buying and selling ready-to-wear clothes. She then pushed through with this venture until today. Mainly, Remelina’s business is rug-making. She uses cheap raw materials to come up with nice rugs for sale. Aside from that, she also sells electronic load for mobile phones which is much in demand nowadays. With all these businesses Remelina earns around Php 10,000 per month.

Knowing that she’ll be needing more finances to help her grow her business, Remelina applies for a Php 21,000 loan. She will use this money to purchase raw materials necessary for rug-making. Also, part of the loan will go to the improvement of the family comfort room.

Financial needs such as medication for her ailing mother bother Remelina. But despite these struggles she knows she has to continue the operation of her business, since this will be one way which God will use to give them financial provision. Remelina is hopeful, knowing that soon she will be able to relocate the site of her store. More than anything, she desires to see her family grow closer to God and have a good life. She yearns to see her children surpass her and graduate from college.

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: raw materials necessary for rug-making

loans.use: reinvest in her bread business

loans.use: buying additional food for her restaurant

loans.name: Annalene

texts.en:
Annalene M. is from the village of Mambuaya, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 31 years old. Annalene is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Annalene owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods & beverages in the local community. Annalene has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Annalene joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Annalene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Annalene is requesting a new loan of 28,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & breads. This will be the 9th loan taken out by Annalene from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Lucia L. is from the village of Mambuaya, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 58 years old. Lucia is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Lucia owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling firewood, bananas & coconuts in the local community. Lucia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Lucia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Lucia is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional firewood & coconuts for copra to sell. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Lucia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao..

loans.use: to purchase additional firewood & coconuts for copra to sell

location.town: Mambuaya, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a 43-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating food production and cake making businesses.  She lives in Toledo City, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her food production and cake making businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 9,000. Susan is borrowing PHP 15,000 to purchase more stock for her business. This will be her 16th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Susan aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Tum

texts.en: Tum P. is 34 years old and has been selling fresh fish in her village, Kompong Tom province, for more than two years. She sells fish which she buys from her wholesale supplier at a reasonable price. She is married to Sang Rrorng, 38, who works as a taxi driver. Presently, Tum P. uses her existing motorbike to transport her fish to her selling place, but now it is broken. Because of this reason, Tum P. requested a loan in order to buy a used motorcycle for replacing the old broken one.

loans.use: To buy a used motorcycle for replacing the old broken one

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
The success of a person is determined not only by her accomplishments but also by her relationships.  While doing her best to excel in her business, Emma B., 45, also strives to be successful in her relationships. Emma graduated from college and is now married to Nerlito, an electrician. They are raising a family of five children. Two of them are already in college; one is in high school; another one is studying in elementary school, while the youngest one is not yet of school age. Together, they live in Baseco Port Area, Manila.

Emma buys and sells goods. She chooses quality ready-to-wear clothes and other accessories, judging them based on the tastes of her customers, buys them and sells them to her community in Baseco. She has been doing this for 15 years now and is prospering. She earns around Php 12,000 every month.

To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting for a Php 17,000 loan. This money will be used to purchase more clothes, accessories, and other saleable items which she thinks her customers need and want. The loan will be of help to her growing business and help her augment the finances of her family.

Just as she wants to succeed in her business, Emma desires a breakthrough in her relationship with her daughter. Her only daughter has just got married, and recently Emma has a misunderstanding with her regarding the married life of her daughter. This is one problem Emma cares about deeply in her heart. But she knows this will be resolved soon, if she does not give in to the problem. Emma looks forward to boosting her business and seeing all her children not miss out on the benefits of having finished a degree course, just as she did.

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: restocking inventory

loans.name: Rwenyerere Bakyara Tukwatanise A, Kihihi Group

texts.en: B. Emmy is the leader of Rwenyerere Bakyara Tukwatanise A, Kihihi. He is 43 years old and married with 7 children, all of them in school. Emmy is a carpenter from Rwenyerere Cell and he works from his carpentry workshop. He is able to make 100,000 Ugandan shillings  as weekly profits from this business that he started 10 years ago. He also sells produce from his plantations like bananas and maize. He is grateful that he was able to start his carpentry business using proceeds from his produce-selling business. He is very cooperative and hard-working and he hopes for his family to develop and his business to expand. He says with this loan he is going to buy more timber to make furniture at his carpentry workshop.

loans.use: He needs to buy more timber for furniture making at his workshop

loans.name: 33. Thieu Van - Thieu Hoa Group

texts.en:
"Oanh L. T. (8) is a 36 year-old woman living in the town of Thieu Duong Thieu Hoa, Thanh Hoa.  Oanh is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 33 Thieu Van - Thieu Hoa (09.01.33).


Oanh is married and has 2 school-aged children.  To make a living, Oanh operates a family member's business raising livestock.  The main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising cattL. for saL..  Oanh has been engaged in this business for over 17 years and earns approximately 1,500,000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2011, Oanh joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Oanh is requesting her first loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.    She is now requesting a new loan of 5,787,900 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  The loan will be the 1st loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Oanh plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  L. T. Hien (9) is a 22 year-old woman who is requesting a 5,787,900 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


2.  L. T. Phuong (10) is a 26 year-old woman who is requesting a 5,787,900 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Oanh L. T. (8) là 36 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thieu Duong Thieu Hoa Thanh Hoa.  Oanh là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 3 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 33 Thieu Van - Thieu Hoa (09.01.33).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gia súc để bán.  Oanh thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 17 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Oanh kiếm được khoảng 1.500.000 VND.  Vào 2011, Oanh đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Oanh đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.    Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.787.900 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là khoản vay 1st của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  L. T. hien (9) là 22 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.787.900 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  L. T. phuong (10) là 26 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.787.900 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Belen

texts.en:
What is astonishing about Belen A., 38, is the big family that she has. She and her husband, Eugenio, raise a family of seven children. One of them is in college, four are in high school, one studies in elementary, while the youngest is not yet of school age. Belen is determined to make sure that her family stays happy and is well-provided for. They live in Baseco Port Area, Manila.

To meet the needs of her big family, Belen runs a sari-sari (variety) store of her own. Belen also manages the rooms she rents out to boarders. She sees to it that her relationships with these boarders is good so that she can secure a long-term business connection with them. These businesses have been operating for six years now, and through them Belen earns Php12,000 per month on average.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting Php34,000 loan. She intends to use this to replenish store products and maintain the rooms being rented out. With sufficient money on hand she can keep up the good condition of her businesses.

A smooth, peaceful life is what Belen desires. Sometimes, however, there is the challenge of unpaid debts of her customers.  Nonetheless, her determination to keep going and keep earning for the future of her children allows her to be strong. She hopes to see all of her children finish college.

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Restocking inventory

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita C. is from the village of Quary, Pagalungan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 40 years old. Clarita is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Clarita owns & operates a business selling green bananas, corn grains & coconuts in the local community. Clarita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Clarita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Clarita is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional coconuts & bananas to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Clarita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

texts.en:
"Xuyen N. T. (11) is a 41 year-old woman living in the town of T. Tran Van Ha Thieu Hoa, Thanh Hoa.  Xuyen is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 31 Van Ha Town Thieu Hoa (12.08.31).


Xuyen is married and has one school-aged child.  To making a living, Xuyen owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling school products, such pencils, pen & notebooks in the local community.  Xuyen has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2,600,000 VND a monT. from these activities.


In 2011, Xuyen joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Xuyen is requesting a first loan of 5,787,900 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  The loan will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  The loan will be the 1st loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Xuyen plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  N. T. Nhung (5) is a 37 year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5,787,900 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector running a general store.


2.  L. T. Duyen (12) is a 30 year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5,787,900 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store.


3.  L. T. Quyen (8) is a 33 year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5,787,900 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector running a general store.


4.  D. T. Canh (10) is a 61 year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5,787,900 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector running a general store.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Xuyen N. T. (11) là 41 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở T.ành phố T. tran van ha Thieu Hoa Thanh Hoa.  Xuyen là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các T.ành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi T.ành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các T.ành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.  Tên chính T.ức của nhóm vay này là 31 T. Tran Van Ha Thieu Hoa (12.08.31).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương T.ức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các đồ dùng học tập như bút chì, bút viết & tập vở trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Xuyen T.ực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 10 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Xuyen kiếm được khoảng 2.600.000 VND.  Vào 2011, Xuyen đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có T.ể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Xuyen đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.    Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.787.900 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông T.ôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
A typical mother’s life often revolves around the lives of her children. Zenaida Requentosa, 47, is one kind of a typical mother. She was not able to go to high school, but because she is a community partner in CCT*, she receives entrepreneurial training and biblical encouragement to help her start and run her own business. Zeny, as she is called by friends, is the wife of Rodrigo, a mason, and the loving mother of three children who are all in high school.  They live in Baseco, Manila.

Zeny runs a business in which balut (fertilized duck egg with an undeveloped embryo) is made and sold to the community. Balut is a common food in the country and is often sought after at night. Zeny capitalizes on this big market and produces quality balut. She also adds fish and pork crackers, which are the best accompaniment for balut. Zeny has been in this business for seven years  and earns around Php12,000 every month.

To help her grow her business, Zenaida seeks a Php17, 000 loan. She intends to use this to improve her balut-making business—buying quality ingredients, paying hired men, and other business expenses. She is sure that the loan will increase the profitability of her business and will help finance the schooling of her three children.

Zenaida worries about the financial stability of her family.  There are times when the balut sales are low, and some customers who borrow do not pay. Nevertheless, she does not give up hoping and believing that her business will grow, and that it will be God’s way of blessing her family with a life of peace and good health.

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase more raw balut eggs for selling

loans.name: Pet

texts.en: From Kompong Tom province, Pet T., age 38, is a married woman who makes a living by selling different kind of desserts in the local school. She has been in this business since 2005. Pet T. was married, but she divorced from her husband when her two children were young. Recently, Pet T. is not comfortable, because her toilet is too old and it often makes some bed smelling. She really wants to build a new toilet for her family but she lacks enough money to build it. To solve this situation, Pet T. is requesting a loan from Kiva to build a new toilet for her family using.

loans.use: To build a new toilet for her family using.

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 29 years old, married and has two children. In 2008, Ali opened his own business for photocopying and selling mobiles and stationary. He is well known in his area and has an excellent reputation.

Ali is requesting a $3000 loan to buy a new photocopier and a generator. He is planning to increase his revenues through developing his business.

loans.name: Narine

texts.en: Narine A. is from the village of Kamo in the Shirak region of Armenia. She is married, with a six year old daughter. Narine has a high school education. She considers herself a hard-working, kind person. She has been engaged as an agricultural entrepreneur for the past five years, and is looking for a loan to purchase livestock. With this investment, she expects the family income to increase by 25 percent. Narine’s dream is to save enough money to purchase a new family house. She enjoys living in Kamo and is surrounded by many relatives and friends.

loans.use: To buy livestock.

loans.name: Ofelya

texts.en: Ofelya Hambarcumyan is from the village of Vahramaberd in the Shirak region of Armenia. She is married, and is the proud mother of five children—three daughters (four, six and ten years old) and two sons (15 and 16 years old). Ofelya has a medical condition but is still able to raise her children and work on the family farm. For the past 16 years she has been raising cattle and growing vegetables. She would like a loan to purchase seed potatoes, fuel, and fertilizer. According to her business plan, she expects the family income to increase by 20 percent. She enjoys living in Vahramaberd, as she has good relationships with all of its residents. Ofelya’s wish is for all of her children to receive a college education.

loans.use: To buy seed potatoes, fuel, and fertilizer.

loans.name: Grace Achieng

texts.en:
Grace N. is a single mother of four children who are all in school. They live in Migori town.

Grace has a business selling second-hand clothes and curtains. She has been doing this business for the past 12 years and has seen her business grow through the years. 

Grace is applying for her first loan from KADET LTD., which will enable her to buy more clothes and curtains to add to her stock. The profits made from this business will be used to pay school fees for her children.

Her desire is to be able to open up a boutique in the future.

loans.use: To buy clothes and curtains to add to her stock

loans.name: Emprendamos El Futuro Group

texts.es:
Los socios pertenecen al banco comunal “EMPRENDAMOS EL FUTURO”; Este banco se ubicada en el distrito D. Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia D. Cusco y departamento D. Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Jacinta; ella tiene 55 años D. edad y es divorciado y tiene 4 Hijos; La socia  tiene un negocio D. tienda D. abarrotes, la socia venD. productos D. primera necesidad como arroz, azúcar, leche, fideos entre otros, la socia atienD. desD. las 5:00 a.m hasta las 10:00 p.m, la socia por medio D. este negocio saca adelante a sus hijos, la socia quiere ampliar y mejorar el negocio D. tienda D. abarrotes.  La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar productos al por mayor para la tienda D. abarrotes.

Los otros socios  se dedican a la venta D. ropa, venta D. fruta, servicio D. verduras, venta D. alimentos y tienda D. abarrotes.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos D. su cuota.
texts.en:
Here are members of the communal bank named "Emprendamos el futuro". This bank is located in the district of Cusco, belonging to the province of Cusco and the department of Cusco.

This member's name is Jacinta. She is 55 years old, divorced, and she has 4 children.  She has a convenience store business. She sells basic needs products such as rice, sugar, milk, pastas and others. She works from 5am until 10pm. She is able to support her children through this business. She wants to expand and improve her convenience store business. She requests a loan to purchase products in wholesale for her convenience store.

She is happy to receive this loan and she is committed to making the payments.

loans.use: To purchase grocery store merchandise in wholesale.

loans.name: Las Gardenias Group

texts.es: Matilde es una nueva socia de la Alcancía Comunal “Las Gardenias” tiene 58 años de edad  y nueve hijos, de los cuales 2 aun dependen de ella, su hija de 23 años de edad estudia economía en la Universidad Mayor de San Marcos y su hijo de 16 años aun está en la secundaria. Matilde se encarga de cubrir todos los gastos de sus hijos y los gastos de la casa ya que su esposo se encuentra desaparecido hace muchos años, es una madre ejemplar ya que con mucho esfuerzo y trabajo pudo criar a sus hijos y aun sigue trabajando, ella se dedica a la ventas de verduras y cereales frescos  y algunos tubérculos, Matilde se encarga personalmente de traerlos de la chacra (sierra central). Ella solicitó el préstamo para comprar papa, queso, choclo, olluco, arvejas y carne.  Matilde sueña con tener una bodega en su casa y de esta manera asegurar su futuro. En la fotografía podemos apreciar a 9 socios del grupo en el momento de su respectivo desembolso y una de las socias acompañada de su niña.  El señor V. P. Edgardo Humberto no pudo asistir al desembolso por motivos de trabajo.
texts.en: Matilde, 58, is a new member of the Las Gardenias community bank.  She has nine children, two of whom still depend on her: a daughter, 23, who is a student of economics at the Universidad Mayor de San Marcos and a son, 16, who is still in high school.  Matilde is responsible for supporting the children and paying the family's other expenses because her husband abandoned the family several years ago.  She is an amazing mother who has managed to raise her children while working hard to support them.  Matilde operates a business selling fresh vegetables and grains, along with other produce.  She buys the products herself from a farm in the country and brings them to her town for sale.  She is applying for a loan so that she can buy potatoes, cheese, beans and meat that she will resell.  Matilde would like to open a store in her house one day, a step that would ensure her future.  There are 9 members of the community bank in the photograph, one of whom brought her little daughter.  Sr. V. P. Edgardo Humberto wasn't able to attend the session, taken when she funds were distributed, because he had to work.
